awd_titl_txt: Exploring a role for the yeast Rat1 protein in pre-mRNA splicing
awd_abstract_narration:
In eukaryotic cells like budding yeast, the transfer of information from DNA to RNA during gene expression requires many steps.  How the individual processes are coordinated remains unclear.  This project will study a protein, called Rat1, which is hypothesized to have a previously unrecognized role in linking early and late steps in RNA synthesis. The outcomes will provide new insights into how gene expression processes are orchestrated.  Involvement of students in the research will contribute to preparation of the next generation of STEM workers.     

This project will study the possible role of the yeast Rat1 protein in coordinating transcription with splicing and mRNA export.  The initial reports of Rat1 implicated this protein in transcription termination and in mRNA export, but recently obtained evidence indicates that mutants deficient in Rat1 activity accumulate unspliced RNAs.  This suggests a role for Rat1 in pre-mRNA splicing; if true, this could explain the previously observed effect on nucleocytoplasmic transport of RNA, as unspliced RNAs are not exported efficiently.  To test this idea, two aims are proposed.  The first will determine if Rat1 associates with spliceosomes.  The second will use two approaches (cross-linking in vivo and splicing in vitro) to test directly for a role of Rat1 in splicing.  The results would contribute to a holistic picture of a role of Rat1 in linking disparate steps in RNA-mediated gene expression.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

This project contributed both in terms of the ‘intellectual merit’ and the ‘broader impact’ criteria as described in NSF guidelines. The following are the outcomes of the project during this reporting period in terms of these two criteria.

 

Intellectual Merit

The Human Genome Project has identified more than 25,000 genes in our cells. Not all of these genes are expressed at the same time or in every cell of our body. A fundamental question in gene expression is how the coordinated expression of genes is achieved during growth, development and homeostasis. Regulation of transcription occurs at multiple steps. The classical view is that factors play step-specific roles during different steps of transcription and cotranscriptional RNA processing. Thus promoter-bound factors are dedicated to initiation and terminator-bound factors are committed to termination of transcription. In our previous NSF funded grant, we demonstrated that the promoter-bound factors affect termination while terminator-bound factors affect promoter-associated transcription. Here we extend these studies and show for the first time that a termination factor, Rat1, has an additional role in cotranscriptional splicing or removal of introns from the primary transcripts. Rat1 is a part of different complexes depending on its intracellular localization. In soluble cellular fractions, Rat is in complex with several splicing factors, while in chromatin context it is in a megacomplex with TFIIB, RNAPII and termination factors.

 

Broader Impact

This NSF grant provided a unique educational opportunity for training students in research, particularly those from underrepresented and economically weaker groups. At least three graduate students working in the PI’s laboratory for a PhD degree benefitted from this grant. One of these PhD students have completed and defended his PhD thesis during the duration of this project and has moved to Harvard Medical School as a post-doctoral trainee. Michael is another graduate student working on this project. He is a local student who was also an undergrad at Wayne State University and decided to pursue research as a career. He benefitted immensely from this NSF grant and will defend his PhD thesis in a few months. Another student, Katie Dwyer, is a local student. She worked as an undergrad researcher in my laboratory in my previous NSF-funded grant. The exposure to research helped her in choosing research as a career. She is now working on this project as a PhD student.  Zulifa is a MA student, who is from an underrepresented minority group, joined the lab during this reporting period. Savannah Kozole is a MA student. She started working in the lab during late winter this year. The research experience helped her in deciding to take up research as a career. She is all set to apply to the PhD program at the end of the year

 

In addition, this grant provided training opportunities for undergraduate students. These students worked in the laboratory for at least two semesters. They attended lab meetings and journal club and present their work in lab meeting. Four undergrads, Alisa Giga, Zahid Aref, Hesham Elewa and Marva Malik, who worked during 2019 and 2020, are authors in publications. Emma Fidler, Mary Ann Essak and Alden Kajy are current undergraduate students working on the grant. Emma will be authors in two publications incoming year. The training opportunities provided by this grant will expose undergraduate students to the intricacies of research and may motivate them to contemplate a career in scientific research. Emma is all set to apply for PhD program.

 

This grant has resulted in one review article during this reporting period. One primary research article is in preparation and will be communicated to a reputed journal soon.
